public static void Add<T>(this Entity entity)

Parameters

Type Parameters

DestroyWithReason(Entity)

Destroys an entity with proper cleanup and logging.

public static void DestroyWithReason(this Entity entity)

Parameters

entity Entity

The entity to destroy

Examples

someEntity.DestroyWithReason();

Remarks

This method follows the recommended destruction pattern:

  1. Disables the entity
  2. Creates a destroy event for tracking
  3. Performs the actual entity destruction

Disabled(Entity)

Checks if an entity is currently disabled.

public static bool Disabled(this Entity entity)

Parameters

entity Entity

The entity to check

Returns

bool

True if the entity has the Disabled component, false otherwise

Examples

if (entity.Disabled()) { // Handle disabled entity logic }

Exists(Entity)

Checks if an entity currently exists in the game world.

public static bool Exists(this Entity entity)

Parameters

entity Entity

The entity to check

Returns

bool

True if the entity exists, false if it has been destroyed or is invalid

Examples

if (entity.Exists()) { // Perform operations on the existing entity }

TryGetComponent<T>(Entity, out T)

Attempts to get a component of type T from the entity.

public static bool TryGetComponent<T>(this Entity entity, out T componentData) where T : struct

Parameters

entity Entity

The entity to get the component from

componentData T

When this method returns, contains the component data if found, or the default value if not found

Returns

bool

True if the component was found and retrieved, false otherwise

Type Parameters

T

The type of component to retrieve. Must be a struct.

Examples

if (entity.TryGetComponent<HealthComponent>(out var health)) { // Work with health component }

Remarks

This method provides a safe way to retrieve components without throwing exceptions.

Write<T>(Entity, T)

Writes component data to an entity using raw memory operations.

public static void Write<T>(this Entity entity, T componentData) where T : struct

Parameters

entity Entity

The target entity to write the component data to

componentData T

The component data to write

Type Parameters

T

The type of component data to write.

Examples

entity.Write(new MyComponentData { value = 42 });

Remarks

This method uses unsafe code to directly manipulate memory for efficient component data writing. The component data is marshaled to a byte array before being written to the entity.
